thread.title: Man splurges RM30,000 on rose-money bouquet
thread.title_full: Man splurges RM30,000 on rose-money bouquet

title: Man splurges RM30,000 on rose-money bouquet
text:
Thursday, 23 February 2017 Man splurges RM30,000 on rose-money bouquet 
A MAN in Butterworth forked out RM30,000 to surprise his girlfriend with a bouquet of 99 roses made from RM100 bills, China Press reported. 
It took three RM100 notes to make each rose, said Unique Florist Art Academy marketing manager Jack Lee. 
“Each rose took about five minutes and the bouquet took about a week to make,” he said. 
The customer collected the bouquet on Saturday. 
> Two college students had the fright of their lives when they came across a half-naked man masturbating in their hostel. 
Sin Chew Daily reported that an 18-year-old student from Betong, Sarawak, and her roommate saw the man engaging in the act outside their room when they were walking to the hostel’s shared bathroom. 
The man was naked from the waist down and wore a full-face helmet when spotted at about 7am on Monday at a shophouse which was used as the hostel in Jalan Setia Raja, Kuching. 
According to the first student, who lodged a police report, she and her roommate screamed when they saw the man. 
The man chased them when they ran and the duo rushed into a room where two other girls were inside. 
The victim said the man knocked on the door, asking them to open up before he fled. 
When they finally did 30 minutes later, they found traces of seminal fluid on the door. 
> The daily also reported that an octogenarian lodged a police report alleging that one of her daughters-in-law abused her. 
The elderly woman told police that her daughter-in-law, in her 40s, with whom she was staying, splashed water on her around 9am on Tuesday. 
She shouted for help, which alerted her son and his wife who live nearby. They took her to a police station to make a report. 
> Found in translation is compiled from the vernacular newspapers (Bahasa Malaysia, Chinese and Tamil dailies). As such, stories are grouped according to the respective language/medium. Where a paragraph begins with a >, it denotes a separate news item.
